title: BIFX 552 - Bioinformatics Data Skills
text:
Syllabus

Course Description
This class provides an introduction to applied data science skills needed by bioinformatics professionals. A focus will be placed on reproducible bioinformatics research and will include the following topics and tools: beginning to intermediate use of the Unix command line, working with remote computing resources, version tracking, R and Bioconductor, tools for manipulating sequence data, and creation of pipelines.

Instructor: Randall Johnson, PhD
Office hours: Office hours will be held immediately before and after in-person meetings. Email me to schedule a virtual office hour at another time.
Prerequisites: BIFX 503
Textbooks: We will not be using a textbook this term, but you may find the following helpful. All are freely available online.

R for Data Science
Advanced R
R Packages

Communications: Course communications will be posted on Blackboard.
Code of Conduct: We want to foster a safe, enjoyable and productive learning environment. People like you add value to our program. To meet this end, all participants will be expected to follow the course code of conduct located in the course documents on Blackboard.
GradCare: Graduate school can be stressful. Hood College is here to help. We offer a wide range of support services for graduate students. Our programs and resources address the eight dimensions of wellness—emotional, physical, social, intellectual, spiritual, occupational, financial and environmental—so you can stay healthy while maintaining school-work-life balance.
Accessibility: As the instructor of this course, I endeavor to provide an inclusive learning environment. However, if you experience barriers to learning in this course, do not hesitate to discuss them with me and the Office for Accessibility Services, 301-696-3421, gmuer@hood.edu.



Learning Objectives
On completion of this course, students should be comfortable with the following:

Use of R and Bioconductor to perform bioinformatic analysis tasks
Use of the Unix command line to manipulate data and perform bioinformatic analysis tasks
Logging into and using remote computing resources
Working with version controlled code repositories in a collaborative work environment
Stitching a series of commands and/or programs together into a reusable pipeline



Asynchronous and In-Person Content
Asynchronous content will be posted weekly, and in-person labs will be scheduled on Tuesday evenings throughout the term at 5:30 PM (see the schedule below). If you need to attend a particular class virtually (e.g. while on travel), in-person labs can be streamed. Course content will be based on up-to-date, publicly available material from experts in the Data Carpentry, Software Carpentry, and Bioconductor communities.


Homework and Course Project
There will be homework assignments associated with each course module. This will give you an opportunity to practice what we cover each week. Homework from asynchronous content will be due on Tuesdays and should be completed before each in-person meeting. The last few weeks of the course will be devoted to a group project based on a bioinformatics workflow from Bioconductor.


Grading
Grades will be based on completion of homework, a group project and two exams.

Asynchronous Content - 25%
In-person Content - 25%
Bioconductor Project - 10%
Mid-term - 20%
Final exam - 20%

Late submissions of any work will be subject to a 5% penalty for each day past the due date. The maximum penalty for late work will be 50%.


Weather
In the event of severe weather resulting in the closure of Hood College and the cancellation of an in-person meeting, the meeting will be held virtually at the scheduled time and a recording posted on Blackboard for asynchronous viewing.

The iris dataset
We are going to start with the iris demo from Rpubs.com, and then we’ll go back and make some upgrades to the formatting.

Required

Start by replicating the information and formatting found at https://rpubs.com/moeransm/intro-iris (export HTML code). Be sure to leave a note attirbuting the original authors.
Set up a repository using this GitHub Classroom link and push your code and html output to GitHub.
Export your document in Word format and submit it on Blackboard.



Optional

Set up GitHub pages on your repository.
Now make it so that the user can opt for dark mode.
Turn the paragraph starting “The summary() function gives summary statistics for any dataset.” into at tip using a callout block.
Fold the code in the visualization section, such that only the figures are shown by default.
